messages.content: What is ExifReader and what file types does it support?

ExifReader is a JavaScript library that parses image files and extracts the metadata. It supports JPEG, TIFF, PNG, HEIC, and WebP files with Exif, IPTC, XMP, ICC, and MPF metadata (depending on file type).
Can ExifReader extract an embedded thumbnail from image files?
Yes, ExifReader can extract an embedded thumbnail from JPEG files.
How customizable is the ExifReader bundle size?

ExifReader can be highly customizable in terms of bundle size. The resulting bundle can be as small as 4 KiB (gzipped) if you're only interested in a few tags. It also allows configuring a custom build to reduce the bundle size significantly.
Does ExifReader support various module formats?
Yes, ExifReader supports module formats ESM, AMD, CommonJS, and globals and can therefore easily be used from Webpack, RequireJS, Browserify, Node etc.
How does ExifReader handle GPS data in images?

GPS data in images is split into two different tags for each direction: the coordinate value (GPSLatitude, GPSLongitude) and the reference value (GPSLatitudeRef, GPSLongitudeRef). Use the references to know whether the coordinate is north/south and east/west. ExifReader also provides pre-calculated values for GPSLatitude, GPSLongitude, and GPSAltitude that are negative for values that are south of the equator, west of the IRM, or below sealevel.
What is the purpose of the Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct for ComfyUI-JNodes?

The purpose of the Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct is to foster an open and welcoming environment and ensure that participation in the project is a harassment-free experience for everyone, regardless of various personal attributes.
What are some examples of behavior that contributes to a positive environment for ComfyUI-JNodes?

Examples include using inclusive language, being respectful of differing viewpoints, gracefully accepting constructive criticism, focusing on what is best for the community, and showing empathy towards other community members.
What can project maintainers do if a contributor does not align with the Code of Conduct?

Project maintainers have the right and responsibility to take appropriate and fair corrective action, including removing, editing, or rejecting contributions, or banning a contributor temporarily or permanently.
Who can be reported for instances of unacceptable behavior in the ComfyUI-JNodes community?

Instances of inappropriate behavior can be reported to mattias@mattiaswallander.com. All complaints will be reviewed and investigated, and a response deemed necessary and appropriate to the circumstances will be provided.
Where can I find more details about the enforcement of the Code of Conduct for ComfyUI-JNodes?
You can find answers to common questions about this code of conduct at <https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq>.
How can I contribute to the ComfyUI-JNodes project?

There are several ways to contribute and all are welcome, such as sending in suggestions for better documentation, creating issues, or creating pull requests for changes or additions. You can also participate in writing bug-fixes, tests, and documentation.
What information should I include when reporting bugs in ComfyUI-JNodes?
When reporting bugs, include a description of the issue and how to reproduce it according to the issue template, and if possible, an example JPEG image where the problem can be seen.
What should I consider when creating a pull request for ComfyUI-JNodes?

Pull requests should follow ESLint rules and be covered by unit tests. Running the linter and tests is easy after 'npm install', using 'npm run lint' and 'npm test'. To specifically look at test code coverage, use 'npm run coverage'.
What are the guidelines for writing a commit message in ComfyUI-JNodes?

The commit message should be descriptive and have an explanatory body if needed. It should be written in the imperative mood, with 50 characters as a soft limit and 72 as a hard limit for the subject line. For non-trivial changes, add a body to explain what was changed and why, wrapping the lines of the body at 72 characters.
